text: The Vipassana Support Institute presents a talk by Shinzen Young entitled, Happiness for No Reason. It was recorded in Santa Barbara, California on December 29, 2000. And now, Shinzen Young. There's an interesting word in the Sanskrit language. It's not a Buddhist term. It's used in some schools of Hinduism. And the word is ahetukananda. Some of you may know ananda, what that means. It's a person's name, but it means joy or bliss or happiness. In Sanskrit, ah means without. It's exactly cognate to the Greek of morpheme, alpha privative, as in symmetrical, asymmetrical, and so forth. It negates. Hetu means a cause. So ahetuka would mean without any cause or reason. And ahetukananda would be a joy or happiness that has no particular reason or cause. In other words, independent of conditions. Ordinarily, our idea of happiness is something happens that we like and we're happy. It's true, isn't it? Now, that's certainly a legitimate concept of happiness, but we would have to say that that is hetukananda, OK? That is happiness based on this or that reason, this or that cause. That there could be a happiness not for any particular reason at all, that in fact could arise when there's every reason to be unhappy is a rather extraordinary concept. In the Buddhist world in Southeast Asia, in any event, where the early form of Buddhism called Hinayana, small vehicle, aka Theravada, the teaching of the elders, is practiced, the canonical language is Pali, which although it is not identical to the language the Buddha spoke is similar. And the greeting that is used in that part of the world, even the secular greeting, even within a secular context, but particularly within a Buddhist context, is Sukhi Hotu. Sukhi Hotu is imperative and Sukhi means a happy person. So Sukhi Hotu literally means may you be happy. It comes from the word Sukha, which ordinarily is translated as pleasure. But in this particular case, Sukhi Hotu has a much deeper meaning. It's not really specified is this happiness dependent on conditions, hetu kananda, or is this happiness that is being wished upon you independent of conditions. It's just may you be happy, Sukhi Hotu. That ambiguity is suggestive. It reminds us that in fact as human beings we have these two possibilities and they're both quite legitimate. We have the possibility to get things the way we want to a certain extent and so we're happy. We have a financial situation, relationship, reputation, security of different sorts, knowledge and education, and we're living where we want to live. We are with the kind of people we want to be with. We're doing the kind of stuff we want to do. We have a happiness. Good, that's legitimate. That's hetu kananda. That's happiness because of this or that. But when the Buddhist says Sukhi Hotu, may you be happy, they're implying that. Good. Have a good life. Get things together. Be fortunate. But they're also implying may you be happy independent of conditions also. Well how can we be happy independent of conditions? Think how awesome our dependence on conditions is. It's not just a matter of having the relationship, reputation, and life situation you want being a condition. Having water to drink, having air to breathe is a condition. So if a claim is made that there's happiness independent of conditions and we are to take that claim literally, then this is one hell of a claim. And a person should be very careful making such a claim because the universe may force them to prove it's true in their own personal life. When I was in the early years of my practice, I lived in a Zen temple in Japan called Shokokuji. Basically I had my ordination in 1970 at Mount Koya, which is the center of the Shingon or Japanese Vajrayana tradition related to Tibetan Buddhism. Not that it comes from Tibet, but they both come from late Indic Buddhism. But after a couple years up there, I wanted to spend a summer doing Zen training. So I asked for a letter of introduction from a Japanese university professor who was also a Zen master. I think you must have known Abe Sensei? Oh yeah. And he was very kind and he gave me this letter of introduction so I got into this Zen temple. In fact, it was during that summer on the begging rounds that I discovered the Nikora house. Japanese Zen monastery can be a pretty scary prospect. I know you may think these retreats are challenging, but there's levels and there's levels and there's levels. I could regale you with war stories of what traditional Zen training is like in Japan, but as much fun as it would be to tell it, I think it might actually be rather off-putting. Just let's say that I was 22 years old and really, really scared at the prospect of going into this monastery. Even though it was only for three months, I mean a lot could happen in three months. Anyway, when I went in, Professor Abe, he took me and introduced me to Kajitani Roshi. I don't know if you ever met him. He was quite old at that time. He introduced me and I liked him and he got me all set up to do what I needed to do to go into the Zen temple. But actually, there's not that much you need to do. It's pretty cool. All I needed to do was get the Zen style robes because each sect in Japan has a different style robe. You can tell what sect the monk belongs to and there's several dozen sects in Japan by the cut of the robe. I had Shingon robes, which are actually very old-fashioned Tang dynasty. They go back to the China of the Tang dynasty. I had these Shingon robes, so I had to get the Zen style robes, which are Sung dynasty Chinese clothes basically. Get a different kind of robe. Then beyond that, I have a letter of introduction from somebody that's respected. Then all you have to do is Niwazume Tangaryo to get in. So what is Niwazume Tangaryo? Well, it's two things, Niwazume and Tangaryo. Niwazume is that you go up to the steps of the temple and you put your letter of introduction down on the steps and you request entrance into the temple. Then they summarily refuse you. Then you sit down on the steps for a couple of days. If they're nice, they'll feed you. If not, you just sit there. That's called Niwazume. It means you're stuck in the front yard, literally, Niwazume. What that means in Japanese. And then they come by and they say, okay, well, come on in here. And they got this crappy little room with all sorts of junk and cobwebs and everything. They say, okay, you can stay here. And you're supposed to basically sit for five days only getting up to go to the bathroom and not sleeping at night. And they sort of spy on you. But if it's like an easy temple, then they sort of look the other way late at night. So maybe you can sleep a little bit after that. But if it's a mean temple, you do sit there for five days, day and night. You only get up when you use the facilities. So after that, they come in and it's really funny. They say, right, you've been sitting there for five freaking days, right? And they say, hmm, well, it seems you're rather sincere about this. So they bring out this book and you just sign up and you sign in. And guess what? You're in. No questions asked. No thing about, hey, you're not Japanese, you're a foreigner. No thing about, hey, you belong to the Shingon school, not Zen. No questions asked. If you're willing to put up with that procedure, then you're in. You're in. You're just like everyone else and you're totally accepted. And there you are as a monk. So that was an interesting process. But like I say, the first night, it's really scary. I mean, what have I got myself in for? This kind of thing. So I was really scared and nervous. And before Abe Sensei said goodbye to me, he gave me this book, which was the sayings of Zen master Rinzai. You have to have that. It's in Chinese. Tang Dynasty. It's Tang Dynasty colloquial Chinese. The Zen people were the first people to use what's called Baihua, which is the spoken language as opposed to Wanli, which is the literary Chinese language. But of course, colloquial Chinese of 1,000 years ago is pretty challenging to read nowadays. But anyway, this thing is all in Chinese. And it's the sayings of Zen master Linji. Rinzai is the Japanese calling. And you have to have that because each morning, the Roshi gives what's called Teisho. Some of you have been up to Mount Baldy, and you've heard Sasaki Roshi give Teisho. They read a section from the Chinese, and then the Roshi comments on it. And you have to be able to see it in Chinese. Otherwise, you can't possibly understand what he's saying because they read it in a form of Japanese that's this artificial Japanese created to pronounce ancient Chinese. And it's totally incomprehensible unless you see the written character. So every monk has to have a copy of the book, or you'll never follow the Roshi's. You can't follow the Roshi's Teisho anyway. But you certainly will be totally lost if you don't have the Chinese text that he's commenting on. So I got my copy of the Linji Lu, the Yan Lu, the sayings of Zen master Linji. So here I am the first night that I finally got in, was accepted. And I opened this thing up. Like I said, I was particularly scared and apprehensive. I opened it up. And let's see. I'm trying to remember how to write it. I might not have this right. Some of you will. Philip and Yan Lu will know for sure if I have it right. I opened it up and lo and behold, Abe Sensei had calligraphed a little message to me. Four Chinese characters on the inside of this book. And the timing couldn't have been more perfect. It's like in the depths of this apprehension of like, you know, what's going to happen to me? I'm like, you know, it's like an unknown situation. I know that they're known for their brutality and I'm just a kid. And basically it's just you're being bossed around all the time. Do this, do that. And then you make a mistake and you get verbally or physically slapped around. And it's just that and that and that and that and that day and night. It's like being completely helpless. And so I opened this thing and said, these four Chinese characters jump out of the page. Be the master of every situation. Be the master of every situation. You're going to be somebody's slave for four months. But of course, there was a deep meaning there. What does it mean to be the master of every situation when in fact you're going to be somebody's slave for four months? What does it mean to be the master in each moment of that situation? Well obviously it doesn't mean the ordinary sense of being the master of every situation. In fact, the situation is the antithesis of what we ordinarily think of as being the master of every situation. Those characters just jumped off the page and I knew what he was saying. It was like he was talking right to me. It's like he had read my mind. He was saying that there is a sense of freedom and happiness that is independent of conditions. And you're going to be forced to discover that because conditions ain't going to be so comfortable for the next four months. And that really impacted me. So when Zen masters say be the master of every situation, or when the Hindus talk about ahetukananda, joy that is independent of conditions and circumstances, or when the Buddhists greet saying sukhihoto, it's all saying the same thing. So what are they saying? They're saying that there's another way to look at this whole issue of happiness and freedom. Which is, in addition to getting conditions to be the way we want, we can literally digest, eat up, dissolve, penetrate each source of unhappiness. I promise you, any sense of being less than perfectly happy at any instant, no matter what goes on, can only come through talk, image, and body sensation. How do you know that you're miserable? You got the yadda to yadda, and you got three or four different flavors of sensation in the body, and you got how much negative imagery going on, crazy imagery. Get enough sleep deprivation, you start to see demons and ghouls in your image function. And your talk goes totally psychotic. And you're freezing cold, or if it's summer, mosquitoes are biting the hell out of you. And you're sleep deprived, and your legs are killing you. You're supposed to do this job, and you don't have any idea how to do it, and they're going to yell at you when you do it wrong, which puts you in a very regressed state of like, you're just a dumb kid that can't do anything right. And that's those different fear and humiliation sensations that are filling up your body, in addition to the uncomfortable physical touches of the bugs, or it's too hot or too cold. So you got half a dozen different flavors of physical and emotional discomfort. But hey, guess what? That's body sensation. And you're hallucinating like crazy because of sleep deprivation. Guess what? That's mental images. Or you're imagining demonic, satanic scenes, you know, archetypical horrors or sexually alluring images. Hey, guess what? That's image. And your talks going yadda, yadda, yadda, yadda, yadda, about this is Looney Tunes. And you know, what am I, why am I doing this? And these people are evil. They are, they're getting even for, for Hiroshima. Hey, you could get really out there. Very irrational talk. But guess what? That's talk. All of these sources of unhappiness can be one by one penetrated and experienced completely. And guess what? When you have a complete experience of it, that's a paradoxical experience. Complete, I don't mean complete in the sense of it's complete temporally. I mean complete in the sense that in the moment there is a totality. When you in the moment have a totality of the body image talk state, there's total contact and zero interference. Then the state is both rich and vacuous at the same time. That's part of the paradox. That paradox is known throughout world mysticism. In fact, scholars of comparative mysticism, people who make a profession out of studying a different mystical traditions, have a, an actually a term for that paradox. They call it the plenum vacuum paradox. Plenum in Latin means that which is full and vacuum, V-A-C-U-U-M, means that which is empty. And so this full emptiness, the paradox, they refer to it, the philosophical issue of it is called technically the plenum vacuum paradox or the Kenoma Pleroma are the Greek equivalents. So if there's a source of unhappiness in the moment, big or small, it comes up as body image and talk. If you have a radically full experience, which is to say enough mindfulness and equanimity, then that source of unhappiness is deeply poignant and yet completely non-problematical, which is very paradoxical. You've sort of etched your way through it. You've eaten your way through it. I don't know how else to describe it. You've metabolized that source of unhappiness. And if you do that for each perception that I'm less than completely happy, guess what? The sources of unhappiness are quite finite. We think it's going to go on forever and ever and ever and get infinitely large and eternally long, but it doesn't work that way. And you start to get a visage that there's an end to all of this, and you start to get a sense of happiness not for any particular reason, but simply because there's no reason not to be happy. That's the via negativa, the negative, the negative path. You basically negate the negatives. You don't achieve anything positive, but if you negate the negative, you come to a positive that is utterly independent of conditions and circumstances. And that becomes a fascinating endeavor. Initially our entire preoccupation is get things the way we want so we'll be happy. But at some point a reversal takes place. Instead of 100% time and energy going into get things the way I want so I'll be happy, you know, maybe 90% time and energy goes into that, but 10% time and energy goes into etch my way through the sources of unhappiness and then I'll be happy. And then 20% goes into that, and then 30% goes into that. And then at some point in one's life it's like you don't become indifferent to conditions, but it's like there's a limit to how much we can manipulate conditions. But there's also a limit to how big the sources of unhappiness are. And if you etch through all of that, guess what? You have limitless happiness independent of conditions. So that's what Abe Sensei was trying to convey when he said be the master of every situation. I don't know who it is, who it was, but one of the Western Buddhist teachers gave a definition of enlightenment. Maybe you read this someplace. I don't know whether it was Joko Beck or Pema Chodron. I think it was, I can't remember, but anyway, here's how you'll know if you're enlightened. Somebody locks you in a little box and you're never going to see anything or hear anything or move again, but you're not going to die. You're intravenously fed and kept alive for years and years and years. But that prospect is not in the slightest frightening to you. Then you'll know you're enlightened. And you know what? That's a palpable visage. That's not just a story made up to blow somebody's mind. Because how many states of mind and body are going to come up about how miserable you are if you dissolve every single one of them? Then there's nothing to make you miserable anymore. You might say, well, there's nothing to make you happy. There's nothing. It's just nothing at all. But when there's nothing to make you miserable, the entire life of the universe courses through you whether you have eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, or not. This is the awesome undertaking of the Arya Paryesana, the noble quest. It starts by learning how to keep your back straight and your body relaxed. Something very mundane. The posture of meditation. Of course, that's just a strategy, just an artificial thing that we set up. But within that posture, the settledness of the body, the alertness that comes from the spine being straight, we can begin our development of concentration power. If you can develop concentration power, you can use that concentration power for a lot of different things. Yes, you can use it to improve your tennis game and your school performance, but you can also use it to investigate the nature of your experience. As far as we know, the method of using concentration power to analyze, in the original Greek sense of the word, analysis, which means to take a complex system and break it down into its parts. As far as we know, this use of concentration was discovered by the Buddha. Prior to the Buddha's time, people used concentration, and they certainly knew about it. It was there in the yogic tradition of India. But it was used primarily to have experiences of merging, which of course is very good, but not so much for the investigating about the nature of suffering, fulfillment, investigating how the sense of self arises. One of the Buddha's contributions, and there are several, to world spirituality was the discovery that you could use the concentration power to deconstruct the suffering self. The categories that I like to use, mental imagery, internal conversation, body sensation, are not quite the traditional categories of early Buddhism, but the idea is the same. The traditional categories of early Buddhism were the five skandhas. If you want, I can go into a talk about what that's all about, but the terminology is a little bit complex. The basic idea, though, is that when you keep track of just what's there, a kind of freedom arises, and when you lose track of what's there, a kind of bondage arises. The Buddhists were the original analysts, they were the original deconstructionists. So what does deconstruction mean in this case? I mentioned yesterday that the sense of limited identity, the ordinary sense of identity, the sense that I am these thoughts and feelings, comes about when body, image, and talk arise and are subject to unconsciousness and fixation. The unconsciousness in this case means a lack of specificity. You're not precise about exactly what's going on. Is it talk, is it image, is it body? Hence these rather artificial exercises that I give you that you may think are very complex and effortful to try to keep the combinations clear. But there is a reason for that. You discover that as soon as you lose specificity, there's this sense of limited identity, and as soon as you have enough specificity and enough fluidity in these sense gates, that goes away, even though the senses are arising. So that's what we mean by deconstruction or analysis. I can give you some metaphors for this. In traditional Buddhist metaphor that you'll find, for example, in the Melinda-Panya-Sutta, the questions of King Melinda, the metaphor is that of a chariot. If you break the chariot down, what do you have? You have wheels, you have spokes, you have a yoke tree, you have a bed, but there's actually no chariot there, there's just all the parts. I think we can find better metaphors than this, actually. The one that I like to use is a little bit on the mundane side, but many of you have heard it before. It relates to something that is a familiar modern device, which would be a television screen or a television monitor on your computer. I come into the room, your computer is turned on, and you've got white on the screen, you've got black and white. And I claim to you that there is no white on that screen. And you say, are you crazy? Take a look, the screen has white. And I say, no, there is no white to be found on that screen. You want proof? Here, here's a magnifying glass. We agree this does nothing, but enlarge what is. Now you go close to that screen, and you look at that patch of white with this magnifying glass and tell me what you see. And what are you going to see? Little pixels, little dots of red, green, and blue. There's no white to be found on that screen whatsoever. There is a strong impression of white that goes away when you pay attention to exactly what's there and reappears as soon as you lose contact with exactly what's there. Somehow consciousness has the ability to mix those three colors in a way that you don't get something that seems to be a mixture of red, green, and blue. You get a completely different critter, white. Somehow the property whiteness emerges by the losing track of the red, green, blueness. And we don't know quite how the nervous system does that. So my question is, is there any white on that screen? And the answer is, well, yes and no. In a sense there is. You can certainly see it any time you want to look carelessly. But in another sense, there really never was any white to be found if you choose to look carefully all the time. Do we have a limited identity that's limited in time and space, that is fundamentally separate from others and from the universe and from the source of the universe? Our ordinary perception is yes. However much we may believe there's some other spiritual truth, our basic perception is the bottom line is I, me, and mine. And it's my career, my health situation, my financial situation. This is me. This is who I am. This is the bottom line. That is a very strong perception. But it turns out that if you keep track of talk, image, and body, then you just have talk, image, and body. And that they don't somehow unconsciously intertwine to produce the sense of limited suffering, vulnerable self. So then what arises? Well the self that is not limited, vulnerable, suffering, and so forth. Well what kind of self is that? It's a paradoxical self. In a sense, it's a very rich self because you're in total contact with your sensory experience and you are not at all in the slightest interfering with its natural flow. So in a sense it's a very rich self. But in another sense it's no self at all. In other words, when you break it down into talk, image, and body and you get enough clear contact the somethingness of self goes away. The Jewish mystics called this experience B'Tul Hayesh. B'Tul in Hebrew means annihilation. Ha means the or of the and yesh means somethingness. The annihilation of the somethingness inside of us. And it was looked upon as the necessary condition for experiencing B'Tul Hayesh Me'ayin. The continuous B'ah, creation, manifestation, yesh of something, Me from, Ayin, the divine nothing. So you don't have to fear the experience of the breaking down of the sense of self, the annihilation of the somethingness in the self, by simply paying attention to exactly what's there. You don't have to fear that experience first of all because after all you're only paying attention to exactly what's there. But secondly, you will not only experience the reabsorption back into the divine void, you will also experience how the divine void manifests you, re-manifests you. And how is that come about? It is vibrating space. That's what light is. So what's talk, image and body? After you've cleared away the gross somethingness of self, and now you know, well okay, they can't weave their illusion, their impression of this limited identity, but hey, there's still all this talk, image and body going on. As you penetrate it more deeply, it starts to show you its waveforms. Guess what? It's vibrating space. And therefore linked to all the other vibrations of space. And what happens when those vibrations stop for a moment? Then you get the real annihilation of somethingness. You get shalom bimromav, to use the words of the Hebrew mystics. That means the divine peace. This word shalom is very interesting as a Semitic word in general and specifically as a Hebrew word. Of course it means peace, but it means so much more. The permutations are difficult to convey to someone that does not speak a Semitic language. Because the Semitic language is like Arabic, Hebrew, Arabic the language of Mohammed, Hebrew the language of the Old Testament prophets, and Aramaic the language of Jesus. These languages are so different from Indo-European languages. The root shin, lamed, mem means completion or totality. That's why shalem, if you happen to know Hebrew, shalem means total or complete. Shlemut is completeness. Then what does this have to do with peace? Well the idea is that when there is peace, when you complete an activity, then there can be a sense of settledness or rest or peace or safety. It is the same root of course that is found in the word Islam and gives us muslim. Muslim is a person that has come to that peacefulness and safety that is the result of having completed an activity. And when you complete the body, image, and talk, not as things but as vibrating activities when all of that vibration ceases of its own, then that is the true shalom bimromav. That is the ayin, the nothing, the divine nothing. When you say nothing it sounds bleak. What's the difference between the nihil of the Christian mystic and the nihil of the nihilist? It's the same Latin word. The difference is how you get there. If you get there through a process of completing the activity of self, you find that the rest is a rich, extremely rich and fulfilling one. If you get there through just being hopeless and confused, you find that the nothing of the existentialist leaves you very, very hungry indeed. So on the metaphor of the television and the red, green, and blue, at one level there is no white, but at a deeper level there is a spirit which is the vibration of this light. And you might think, oh, okay, so then the goal of this practice is to experience this vibrating flow of spirit. But actually the goal is to deconstruct it into body, image, talk, and then deconstruct body, image, talk into expanding and contracting, and then to allow all of that to stop of its own. And then to allow that activity to repolarize and to allow yourself to be reborn in the formless folds of this vibrating womb of spirit, and then allow yourself to be reabsorbed and reborn and reabsorbed and reborn over and over hundreds of times a day, day after day after day, the cycle of crucifixion and resurrection. To what end? Well, in the words of the Jewish mystics, something called tikkun olam. Boy, is that an interesting phrase. In Hebrew it means the mending of the world, the mending of the world. It is said that the tzaddik, which is a saint or an enlightened person in Hebrew, the plural being tzaddikim, the tzaddikim by in a small way participating in the divine activity of bitul ha-yesh b'ah yesh me'ayim, by participating on a day to day basis, allowing oneself to dissolve and be reborn. By doing that, one contributes to the evolution of the world, to bringing about the Messiah. I don't exactly ascribe to messianic concepts of history myself, but we can take it in a little broader context. You can consider the messianic age to be what would happen if large numbers of people were to take on the path of enlightenment. Then that would be the messianic age. So by participating in a small way in this divine doing, it is said that one fosters the healing of the world. And it's quite true, because if you're encountering the spiritual source directly and then arising from that spiritual source, what you do in this world will be of the essence of love and compassion by and large, just naturally. So the ultimate goal of the whole thing is to be of effortless service to this world in various ways. If that's the ultimate goal, one might say, well, why not just cut to the chase? Why bother to go to all the trouble of developing the concentration power, of getting the insights, of seeing beyond the limited identity, with all of the confusion and fear that you have to go through to come to that place? Why not just go out there and start doing good stuff? Well, actually, there's nothing to say that from the beginning you can't just go out there and start doing good stuff. But if you do not also, at least in parallel, do some of the kind of work I'm describing here, guess what? You're going to be subject to, you've all heard me say it, the three outs. Bum out, burn out, freak out. You try to do good, you extend in all sincerity your hand to help, and guess what? They freaking bite it. Are you going to get bummed out? If there hasn't been some vision beyond the limited identity, then hey, they bit my hand. I'm speaking metaphorically here, but you understand what I'm saying. Some part of your ego's anatomy is going to get bit. That can lead to bum out if there's not a certain degree of liberation and purification. And then burn out, well, you know what that is. The deeper you get on the path, the more sensitive you become. Great. But now your body's like a freaking antenna and it picks up all of the negativities of the world. What are you going to do with it? Very very common phenomenon on the spiritual path is people do a practice, they develop a certain depth and sensitivity without insight and equanimity components. And then they're actually, they have a lot of problems because they can't read the newspaper or walk down the street without just picking up so much stuff. I mean, I get people coming to me constantly with this, you know, I've been meditating this way, that way for these years, but I just pick up so much. People come to me and say they don't want to meditate in the group because they pick up all the doo-doo from the group. If you have a certain amount of the liberation aspects, that doesn't become a problem. Because whether it's your doo-doo or the doo-doo that is imposed upon you, other human beings and what they're going through, all of it fertilizes the lotus of your enlightenment. You don't make a distinction between different sources of doo-doo. But see that's the whole point. Well, how do you know you're picking up stuff? You see the images, you get the body sensations, okay? Comes through talk, image, and body. Comes through the very sense gates that you now know how to separate, unblock, and see through. Actually largely through body sensations, but also some people see spirits, they see this, you know, they say, I can see the negative spirits around them, I can see the bad aura around them. That's the image function, okay? Largely body and image, but it could come through talk. It's like, oh, I, you know, that's an evil person, I can tell how he, okay, so you hear the talk, okay, or why do they have to be that way, you know. So it just comes through talk, image, and body, and once you've learned how to tease that skein apart and then get it back into its true nature, just waves that link to the other waves of the universe. So you don't have to worry quite as much about burnout, and then freak out. What do I mean by freak out? Freak out is when you act out of character. In the most extreme forms, you start out trying to help somebody and you end up abusing them. Hey, I don't know about you, but I've been there and done that. Okay? Very, very easy that that can happen. Why does that happen? Well, that happens because of suffering. Suffering distorts perception and behavior. So you freak out in the objective world. You do something that you later regret. That's less likely to happen if you know how to experience pain without suffering, emotional pain without suffering, frustration, confusion, helplessness, embarrassment without suffering as much as most people do. So although the ultimate goal is, yes indeed, to serve, one's service is going to be so much more effective and so much more fun and natural and fulfilling if there is also along with the seva, the aspect of sadhana, that you've worked on yourself for yourself. So that is what this path is about. You could say that it starts with learning to keep your spine straight and it culminates with becoming an effortless source of benefaction to the world around you. This concludes Happiness for No Reason with Shinzen Young. For further information on the Vipassana Support Institute or Shinzen Young, the toll-free number is 866-666-0VSI or visit on the web at www.shinzen.org.

segments.text: The Vipassana Support Institute presents a talk by Shinzen Young entitled, Happiness
for No Reason.
It was recorded in Santa Barbara, California on December 29, 2000.
And now, Shinzen Young.
There's an interesting word in the Sanskrit language.
It's not a Buddhist term.
It's used in some schools of Hinduism.
And the word is ahetukananda.
Some of you may know ananda, what that means.
It's a person's name, but it means joy or bliss or happiness.
In Sanskrit, ah means without.
It's exactly cognate to the Greek of morpheme, alpha privative, as in symmetrical, asymmetrical,
and so forth.
It negates.
Hetu means a cause.
So ahetuka would mean without any cause or reason.
And ahetukananda would be a joy or happiness that has no particular reason or cause.
In other words, independent of conditions.
Ordinarily, our idea of happiness is something happens that we like and we're happy.
It's true, isn't it?
Now, that's certainly a legitimate concept of happiness, but we would have to say that
that is hetukananda, OK?
That is happiness based on this or that reason, this or that cause.
That there could be a happiness not for any particular reason at all, that in fact could
arise when there's every reason to be unhappy is a rather extraordinary concept.
In the Buddhist world in Southeast Asia, in any event, where the early form of Buddhism
called Hinayana, small vehicle, aka Theravada, the teaching of the elders, is practiced,
the canonical language is Pali, which although it is not identical to the language the Buddha
spoke is similar.
And the greeting that is used in that part of the world, even the secular greeting, even
within a secular context, but particularly within a Buddhist context, is Sukhi Hotu.
Sukhi Hotu is imperative and Sukhi means a happy person.
So Sukhi Hotu literally means may you be happy.
It comes from the word Sukha, which ordinarily is translated as pleasure.
But in this particular case, Sukhi Hotu has a much deeper meaning.
It's not really specified is this happiness dependent on conditions, hetu kananda, or
is this happiness that is being wished upon you independent of conditions.
It's just may you be happy, Sukhi Hotu.
That ambiguity is suggestive.
It reminds us that in fact as human beings we have these two possibilities and they're
both quite legitimate.
We have the possibility to get things the way we want to a certain extent and so we're
happy.
We have a financial situation, relationship, reputation, security of different sorts, knowledge
and education, and we're living where we want to live.
We are with the kind of people we want to be with.
We're doing the kind of stuff we want to do.
We have a happiness.
Good, that's legitimate.
That's hetu kananda.
That's happiness because of this or that.
But when the Buddhist says Sukhi Hotu, may you be happy, they're implying that.
Good.
Have a good life.
Get things together.
Be fortunate.
But they're also implying may you be happy independent of conditions also.
Well how can we be happy independent of conditions?
Think how awesome our dependence on conditions is.
It's not just a matter of having the relationship, reputation, and life situation you want being
a condition.
Having water to drink, having air to breathe is a condition.
So if a claim is made that there's happiness independent of conditions and we are to take
that claim literally, then this is one hell of a claim.
And a person should be very careful making such a claim because the universe may force
them to prove it's true in their own personal life.
When I was in the early years of my practice, I lived in a Zen temple in Japan called Shokokuji.

Japanese Vajrayana tradition related to Tibetan Buddhism.
Not that it comes from Tibet, but they both come from late Indic Buddhism.
But after a couple years up there, I wanted to spend a summer doing Zen training.
So I asked for a letter of introduction from a Japanese university professor who was also
a Zen master.
I think you must have known Abe Sensei?
Oh yeah.
And he was very kind and he gave me this letter of introduction so I got into this Zen temple.
In fact, it was during that summer on the begging rounds that I discovered the Nikora
house.
Japanese Zen monastery can be a pretty scary prospect.
I know you may think these retreats are challenging, but there's levels and there's levels and
there's levels.
I could regale you with war stories of what traditional Zen training is like in Japan,
but as much fun as it would be to tell it, I think it might actually be rather off-putting.
Just let's say that I was 22 years old and really, really scared at the prospect of going
into this monastery.
Even though it was only for three months, I mean a lot could happen in three months.
Anyway, when I went in, Professor Abe, he took me and introduced me to Kajitani Roshi.
I don't know if you ever met him.
He was quite old at that time.
He introduced me and I liked him and he got me all set up to do what I needed to do to
go into the Zen temple.
But actually, there's not that much you need to do.
It's pretty cool.
All I needed to do was get the Zen style robes because each sect in Japan has a different
style robe.
You can tell what sect the monk belongs to and there's several dozen sects in Japan by
the cut of the robe.
I had Shingon robes, which are actually very old-fashioned Tang dynasty.
They go back to the China of the Tang dynasty.
I had these Shingon robes, so I had to get the Zen style robes, which are Sung dynasty
Chinese clothes basically.
Get a different kind of robe.
Then beyond that, I have a letter of introduction from somebody that's respected.
Then all you have to do is Niwazume Tangaryo to get in.
So what is Niwazume Tangaryo?
Well, it's two things, Niwazume and Tangaryo.
Niwazume is that you go up to the steps of the temple and you put your letter of introduction
down on the steps and you request entrance into the temple.
Then they summarily refuse you.
Then you sit down on the steps for a couple of days.
If they're nice, they'll feed you.
If not, you just sit there.
That's called Niwazume.
It means you're stuck in the front yard, literally, Niwazume.
What that means in Japanese.
And then they come by and they say, okay, well, come on in here.
And they got this crappy little room with all sorts of junk and cobwebs and everything.
They say, okay, you can stay here.
And you're supposed to basically sit for five days only getting up to go to the bathroom
and not sleeping at night.
And they sort of spy on you.
But if it's like an easy temple, then they sort of look the other way late at night.
So maybe you can sleep a little bit after that.
But if it's a mean temple, you do sit there for five days, day and night.
You only get up when you use the facilities.
So after that, they come in and it's really funny.
They say, right, you've been sitting there for five freaking days, right?
And they say, hmm, well, it seems you're rather sincere about this.
So they bring out this book and you just sign up and you sign in.
And guess what?
You're in.
No questions asked.
No thing about, hey, you're not Japanese, you're a foreigner.
No thing about, hey, you belong to the Shingon school, not Zen.
No questions asked.
If you're willing to put up with that procedure, then you're in.
You're in.
You're just like everyone else and you're totally accepted.
And there you are as a monk.
So that was an interesting process.

I mean, what have I got myself in for?
This kind of thing.
So I was really scared and nervous.

You have to have that.
It's in Chinese.
Tang Dynasty.
It's Tang Dynasty colloquial Chinese.
The Zen people were the first people to use what's called Baihua, which is the spoken

You can't follow the Roshi's Teisho anyway.

Some of you will.
Philip and Yan Lu will know for sure if I have it right.
I opened it up and lo and behold, Abe Sensei had calligraphed a little message to me.
Four Chinese characters on the inside of this book.
And the timing couldn't have been more perfect.
It's like in the depths of this apprehension of like, you know, what's going to happen
to me?
I'm like, you know, it's like an unknown situation.
I know that they're known for their brutality and I'm just a kid.
And basically it's just you're being bossed around all the time.
Do this, do that.
And then you make a mistake and you get verbally or physically slapped around.
And it's just that and that and that and that and that day and night.
It's like being completely helpless.
And so I opened this thing and said, these four Chinese characters jump out of the page.
Be the master of every situation.
Be the master of every situation.
You're going to be somebody's slave for four months.
But of course, there was a deep meaning there.
What does it mean to be the master of every situation when in fact you're going to be
somebody's slave for four months?
What does it mean to be the master in each moment of that situation?
Well obviously it doesn't mean the ordinary sense of being the master of every situation.
In fact, the situation is the antithesis of what we ordinarily think of as being the master
of every situation.
Those characters just jumped off the page and I knew what he was saying.
It was like he was talking right to me.
It's like he had read my mind.
He was saying that there is a sense of freedom and happiness that is independent of conditions.
And you're going to be forced to discover that because conditions ain't going to be
so comfortable for the next four months.
And that really impacted me.
So when Zen masters say be the master of every situation, or when the Hindus talk about ahetukananda,
joy that is independent of conditions and circumstances, or when the Buddhists greet
saying sukhihoto, it's all saying the same thing.
So what are they saying?
They're saying that there's another way to look at this whole issue of happiness and
freedom.
Which is, in addition to getting conditions to be the way we want, we can literally digest,
eat up, dissolve, penetrate each source of unhappiness.
I promise you, any sense of being less than perfectly happy at any instant, no matter
what goes on, can only come through talk, image, and body sensation.
How do you know that you're miserable?
You got the yadda to yadda, and you got three or four different flavors of sensation in

Get enough sleep deprivation, you start to see demons and ghouls in your image function.
And your talk goes totally psychotic.
And you're freezing cold, or if it's summer, mosquitoes are biting the hell out of you.
And you're sleep deprived, and your legs are killing you.
You're supposed to do this job, and you don't have any idea how to do it, and they're going
to yell at you when you do it wrong, which puts you in a very regressed state of like,
you're just a dumb kid that can't do anything right.
And that's those different fear and humiliation sensations that are filling up your body,
in addition to the uncomfortable physical touches of the bugs, or it's too hot or too

So you got half a dozen different flavors of physical and emotional discomfort.
But hey, guess what?
That's body sensation.
And you're hallucinating like crazy because of sleep deprivation.
Guess what?
That's mental images.
Or you're imagining demonic, satanic scenes, you know, archetypical horrors or sexually

Hey, guess what?
That's image.
And your talks going yadda, yadda, yadda, yadda, yadda, about this is Looney Tunes.
And you know, what am I, why am I doing this?
And these people are evil.
They are, they're getting even for, for Hiroshima.
Hey, you could get really out there.
Very irrational talk.
But guess what?
That's talk.
All of these sources of unhappiness can be one by one penetrated and experienced completely.
And guess what?
When you have a complete experience of it, that's a paradoxical experience.
Complete, I don't mean complete in the sense of it's complete temporally.
I mean complete in the sense that in the moment there is a totality.
When you in the moment have a totality of the body image talk state, there's total contact
and zero interference.
Then the state is both rich and vacuous at the same time.
That's part of the paradox.
That paradox is known throughout world mysticism.
In fact, scholars of comparative mysticism, people who make a profession out of studying
a different mystical traditions, have a, an actually a term for that paradox.
They call it the plenum vacuum paradox.
Plenum in Latin means that which is full and vacuum, V-A-C-U-U-M, means that which is empty.
And so this full emptiness, the paradox, they refer to it, the philosophical issue of it
is called technically the plenum vacuum paradox or the Kenoma Pleroma are the Greek equivalents.
So if there's a source of unhappiness in the moment, big or small, it comes up as body
image and talk.
If you have a radically full experience, which is to say enough mindfulness and equanimity,
then that source of unhappiness is deeply poignant and yet completely non-problematical,
which is very paradoxical.
You've sort of etched your way through it.
You've eaten your way through it.
I don't know how else to describe it.
You've metabolized that source of unhappiness.
And if you do that for each perception that I'm less than completely happy, guess what?
The sources of unhappiness are quite finite.
We think it's going to go on forever and ever and ever and get infinitely large and eternally
long, but it doesn't work that way.
And you start to get a visage that there's an end to all of this, and you start to get
a sense of happiness not for any particular reason, but simply because there's no reason
not to be happy.
That's the via negativa, the negative, the negative path.
You basically negate the negatives.
You don't achieve anything positive, but if you negate the negative, you come to a positive
that is utterly independent of conditions and circumstances.
And that becomes a fascinating endeavor.
Initially our entire preoccupation is get things the way we want so we'll be happy.
But at some point a reversal takes place.
Instead of 100% time and energy going into get things the way I want so I'll be happy,
you know, maybe 90% time and energy goes into that, but 10% time and energy goes into etch
my way through the sources of unhappiness and then I'll be happy.
And then 20% goes into that, and then 30% goes into that.
And then at some point in one's life it's like you don't become indifferent to conditions,
but it's like there's a limit to how much we can manipulate conditions.
But there's also a limit to how big the sources of unhappiness are.
And if you etch through all of that, guess what?
You have limitless happiness independent of conditions.
So that's what Abe Sensei was trying to convey when he said be the master of every situation.
I don't know who it is, who it was, but one of the Western Buddhist teachers gave a definition
of enlightenment.
Maybe you read this someplace.
I don't know whether it was Joko Beck or Pema Chodron.
I think it was, I can't remember, but anyway, here's how you'll know if you're enlightened.
Somebody locks you in a little box and you're never going to see anything or hear anything
or move again, but you're not going to die.
You're intravenously fed and kept alive for years and years and years.
But that prospect is not in the slightest frightening to you.
Then you'll know you're enlightened.
And you know what?
That's a palpable visage.
That's not just a story made up to blow somebody's mind.
Because how many states of mind and body are going to come up about how miserable you are

Then there's nothing to make you miserable anymore.
You might say, well, there's nothing to make you happy.
There's nothing.
It's just nothing at all.
But when there's nothing to make you miserable, the entire life of the universe courses through
you whether you have eyes, ears, nose, tongue, body, or not.
This is the awesome undertaking of the Arya Paryesana, the noble quest.
It starts by learning how to keep your back straight and your body relaxed.
Something very mundane.
The posture of meditation.
Of course, that's just a strategy, just an artificial thing that we set up.

If you can develop concentration power, you can use that concentration power for a lot
of different things.
Yes, you can use it to improve your tennis game and your school performance, but you

As far as we know, the method of using concentration power to analyze, in the original Greek sense
of the word, analysis, which means to take a complex system and break it down into its

As far as we know, this use of concentration was discovered by the Buddha.
Prior to the Buddha's time, people used concentration, and they certainly knew about it.
It was there in the yogic tradition of India.
But it was used primarily to have experiences of merging, which of course is very good,
but not so much for the investigating about the nature of suffering, fulfillment, investigating

One of the Buddha's contributions, and there are several, to world spirituality was the
discovery that you could use the concentration power to deconstruct the suffering self.
The categories that I like to use, mental imagery, internal conversation, body sensation,
are not quite the traditional categories of early Buddhism, but the idea is the same.
The traditional categories of early Buddhism were the five skandhas.
If you want, I can go into a talk about what that's all about, but the terminology is a

The basic idea, though, is that when you keep track of just what's there, a kind of freedom
arises, and when you lose track of what's there, a kind of bondage arises.
The Buddhists were the original analysts, they were the original deconstructionists.
So what does deconstruction mean in this case?
I mentioned yesterday that the sense of limited identity, the ordinary sense of identity,
the sense that I am these thoughts and feelings, comes about when body, image, and talk arise
and are subject to unconsciousness and fixation.
The unconsciousness in this case means a lack of specificity.
You're not precise about exactly what's going on.
Is it talk, is it image, is it body?
Hence these rather artificial exercises that I give you that you may think are very complex
and effortful to try to keep the combinations clear.
But there is a reason for that.
You discover that as soon as you lose specificity, there's this sense of limited identity, and
as soon as you have enough specificity and enough fluidity in these sense gates, that
goes away, even though the senses are arising.
So that's what we mean by deconstruction or analysis.
I can give you some metaphors for this.
In traditional Buddhist metaphor that you'll find, for example, in the Melinda-Panya-Sutta,
the questions of King Melinda, the metaphor is that of a chariot.
If you break the chariot down, what do you have?
You have wheels, you have spokes, you have a yoke tree, you have a bed, but there's actually
no chariot there, there's just all the parts.
I think we can find better metaphors than this, actually.
The one that I like to use is a little bit on the mundane side, but many of you have

It relates to something that is a familiar modern device, which would be a television

I come into the room, your computer is turned on, and you've got white on the screen, you've
got black and white.
And I claim to you that there is no white on that screen.
And you say, are you crazy?
Take a look, the screen has white.
And I say, no, there is no white to be found on that screen.
You want proof?
Here, here's a magnifying glass.
We agree this does nothing, but enlarge what is.
Now you go close to that screen, and you look at that patch of white with this magnifying
glass and tell me what you see.
And what are you going to see?
Little pixels, little dots of red, green, and blue.
There's no white to be found on that screen whatsoever.
There is a strong impression of white that goes away when you pay attention to exactly
what's there and reappears as soon as you lose contact with exactly what's there.
Somehow consciousness has the ability to mix those three colors in a way that you don't
get something that seems to be a mixture of red, green, and blue.
You get a completely different critter, white.
Somehow the property whiteness emerges by the losing track of the red, green, blueness.
And we don't know quite how the nervous system does that.
So my question is, is there any white on that screen?
And the answer is, well, yes and no.
In a sense there is.
You can certainly see it any time you want to look carelessly.
But in another sense, there really never was any white to be found if you choose to look
carefully all the time.
Do we have a limited identity that's limited in time and space, that is fundamentally separate

Our ordinary perception is yes.
However much we may believe there's some other spiritual truth, our basic perception

And it's my career, my health situation, my financial situation.
This is me.
This is who I am.
This is the bottom line.
That is a very strong perception.
But it turns out that if you keep track of talk, image, and body, then you just have
talk, image, and body.
And that they don't somehow unconsciously intertwine to produce the sense of limited

So then what arises?
Well the self that is not limited, vulnerable, suffering, and so forth.
Well what kind of self is that?
It's a paradoxical self.
In a sense, it's a very rich self because you're in total contact with your sensory

So in a sense it's a very rich self.
But in another sense it's no self at all.
In other words, when you break it down into talk, image, and body and you get enough clear
contact the somethingness of self goes away.

So you don't have to fear the experience of the breaking down of the sense of self,

You don't have to fear that experience first of all because after all you're only paying

Well we can extend our television metaphor a little bit further.

Well on our metaphor of red green and blue, there's something that red green and blue

After you've cleared away the gross somethingness of self, and now you know, well okay, they

It's vibrating space.
And therefore linked to all the other vibrations of space.
And what happens when those vibrations stop for a moment?

You get shalom bimromav, to use the words of the Hebrew mystics.
That means the divine peace.
This word shalom is very interesting as a Semitic word in general and specifically as

Of course it means peace, but it means so much more.
The permutations are difficult to convey to someone that does not speak a Semitic language.
Because the Semitic language is like Arabic, Hebrew, Arabic the language of Mohammed, Hebrew

These languages are so different from Indo-European languages.
The root shin, lamed, mem means completion or totality.
That's why shalem, if you happen to know Hebrew, shalem means total or complete.
Shlemut is completeness.
Then what does this have to do with peace?
Well the idea is that when there is peace, when you complete an activity, then there
can be a sense of settledness or rest or peace or safety.
It is the same root of course that is found in the word Islam and gives us muslim.
Muslim is a person that has come to that peacefulness and safety that is the result of having completed
an activity.
And when you complete the body, image, and talk, not as things but as vibrating activities

That is the ayin, the nothing, the divine nothing.
When you say nothing it sounds bleak.
What's the difference between the nihil of the Christian mystic and the nihil of the
nihilist?
It's the same Latin word.
The difference is how you get there.
If you get there through a process of completing the activity of self, you find that the rest

If you get there through just being hopeless and confused, you find that the nothing of
the existentialist leaves you very, very hungry indeed.
So on the metaphor of the television and the red, green, and blue, at one level there is

And then to allow that activity to repolarize and to allow yourself to be reborn in the
formless folds of this vibrating womb of spirit, and then allow yourself to be reabsorbed and
reborn and reabsorbed and reborn over and over hundreds of times a day, day after day
after day, the cycle of crucifixion and resurrection.
To what end?
Well, in the words of the Jewish mystics, something called tikkun olam.
Boy, is that an interesting phrase.
In Hebrew it means the mending of the world, the mending of the world.
It is said that the tzaddik, which is a saint or an enlightened person in Hebrew, the plural
being tzaddikim, the tzaddikim by in a small way participating in the divine activity of
bitul ha-yesh b'ah yesh me'ayim, by participating on a day to day basis, allowing oneself to
dissolve and be reborn.
By doing that, one contributes to the evolution of the world, to bringing about the Messiah.
I don't exactly ascribe to messianic concepts of history myself, but we can take it in a
little broader context.
You can consider the messianic age to be what would happen if large numbers of people were
to take on the path of enlightenment.
Then that would be the messianic age.
So by participating in a small way in this divine doing, it is said that one fosters
the healing of the world.
And it's quite true, because if you're encountering the spiritual source directly and then arising
from that spiritual source, what you do in this world will be of the essence of love
and compassion by and large, just naturally.
So the ultimate goal of the whole thing is to be of effortless service to this world
in various ways.
If that's the ultimate goal, one might say, well, why not just cut to the chase?
Why bother to go to all the trouble of developing the concentration power, of getting the insights,
of seeing beyond the limited identity, with all of the confusion and fear that you have
to go through to come to that place?
Why not just go out there and start doing good stuff?
Well, actually, there's nothing to say that from the beginning you can't just go out there
and start doing good stuff.
But if you do not also, at least in parallel, do some of the kind of work I'm describing
here, guess what?
You're going to be subject to, you've all heard me say it, the three outs.
Bum out, burn out, freak out.
You try to do good, you extend in all sincerity your hand to help, and guess what?
They freaking bite it.
Are you going to get bummed out?
If there hasn't been some vision beyond the limited identity, then hey, they bit my hand.
I'm speaking metaphorically here, but you understand what I'm saying.
Some part of your ego's anatomy is going to get bit.
That can lead to bum out if there's not a certain degree of liberation and purification.
And then burn out, well, you know what that is.
The deeper you get on the path, the more sensitive you become.
Great.
But now your body's like a freaking antenna and it picks up all of the negativities of
the world.
What are you going to do with it?
Very very common phenomenon on the spiritual path is people do a practice, they develop
a certain depth and sensitivity without insight and equanimity components.
And then they're actually, they have a lot of problems because they can't read the newspaper
or walk down the street without just picking up so much stuff.
I mean, I get people coming to me constantly with this, you know, I've been meditating
this way, that way for these years, but I just pick up so much.
People come to me and say they don't want to meditate in the group because they pick
up all the doo-doo from the group.
If you have a certain amount of the liberation aspects, that doesn't become a problem.
Because whether it's your doo-doo or the doo-doo that is imposed upon you, other human beings
and what they're going through, all of it fertilizes the lotus of your enlightenment.
You don't make a distinction between different sources of doo-doo.
But see that's the whole point.
If you have a certain degree of the knowledge that I'm talking about, others' smells just
as good as yours, you might say.
There's not that distinction.
And why?
Well, how do you know you're picking up stuff?
You see the images, you get the body sensations, okay?
Comes through talk, image, and body.
Comes through the very sense gates that you now know how to separate, unblock, and see
through.
So it doesn't matter whether it's exogenous or endogenous, whether it's your stuff or
their stuff, it comes through the same sense gates and you've developed insight, purification,
and so forth.
So now you're ready to just take it all on, let it all come, it doesn't make any difference.
It's just more states of body, image, talk.
How do you know you're picking up somebody's doo-doo?
Actually largely through body sensations, but also some people see spirits, they see
this, you know, they say, I can see the negative spirits around them, I can see the bad aura
around them.
That's the image function, okay?
Largely body and image, but it could come through talk.
It's like, oh, I, you know, that's an evil person, I can tell how he, okay, so you hear
the talk, okay, or why do they have to be that way, you know.
So it just comes through talk, image, and body, and once you've learned how to tease
that skein apart and then get it back into its true nature, just waves that link to the
other waves of the universe.
So you don't have to worry quite as much about burnout, and then freak out.
What do I mean by freak out?
Freak out is when you act out of character.
In the most extreme forms, you start out trying to help somebody and you end up abusing them.
Hey, I don't know about you, but I've been there and done that.
Okay?
Very, very easy that that can happen.
Why does that happen?
Well, that happens because of suffering.
Suffering distorts perception and behavior.
So you freak out in the objective world.
You do something that you later regret.
That's less likely to happen if you know how to experience pain without suffering, emotional
pain without suffering, frustration, confusion, helplessness, embarrassment without suffering
as much as most people do.
So although the ultimate goal is, yes indeed, to serve, one's service is going to be so
much more effective and so much more fun and natural and fulfilling if there is also along
with the seva, the aspect of sadhana, that you've worked on yourself for yourself.
So that is what this path is about.
You could say that it starts with learning to keep your spine straight and it culminates
with becoming an effortless source of benefaction to the world around you.
This concludes Happiness for No Reason with Shinzen Young.
